message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Toward Autonomous Multi-UAV Wireless Network: A Survey of Reinforcement Learning-Based Approaches
Paper Abstract: Publisher Copyright: Author
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Based on the search results, here's a comprehensive overview of reinforcement learning:

## What is Reinforcement Learning?

Reinforcement learning (RL) is concerned with how an intelligent agent should take actions in a dynamic environment in order to maximize a reward signal.(no content)It is one of the three basic machine learning paradigms, alongside supervised learning and unsupervised learning.

## How It Works

While supervised learning and unsupervised learning algorithms attempt to discover patterns in labeled and unlabeled data, reinforcement learning involves training an agent through interactions with its environment.(no content)To learn to maximize rewards from these interactions, the agent makes decisions between trying new actions to learn more about the environment (exploration), or using current knowledge of the environment to take the best action (exploitation).

## Key Characteristics

The search for the optimal balance between these two strategies is known as the exploration–exploitation dilemma.(no content)Two elements make reinforcement learning powerful: the use of samples to optimize performance, and the use of function approximation to deal with large environments.

## Applications and Success Stories

It has been applied successfully to various problems, including energy storage, robot control, photovoltaic generators, backgammon, checkers, Go (AlphaGo), and autonomous driving systems.

## Subdisciplines

The field encompasses various specialized areas including:
- Deep reinforcement learning (deep RL), which combines reinforcement learning and deep learning
- Multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL), which focuses on studying the behavior of multiple learning agents that coexist in a shared environment

Reinforcement learning (RL) is concerned with how an intelligent agent should take actions in a dynamic environment in order to maximize a reward signal.(no content)It is one of the three basic machine learning paradigms, alongside supervised learning and unsupervised learning.

## How It Works

While supervised learning and unsupervised learning algorithms attempt to discover patterns in labeled and unlabeled data, reinforcement learning involves training an agent through interactions with its environment.(no content)To learn to maximize rewards from these interactions, the agent makes decisions between trying new actions to learn more about the environment (exploration), or using current knowledge of the environment to take the best action (exploitation).

## Key Characteristics

The search for the optimal balance between these two strategies is known as the exploration–exploitation dilemma.(no content)Two elements make reinforcement learning powerful: the use of samples to optimize performance, and the use of function approximation to deal with large environments.

## Applications and Success Stories

It has been applied successfully to various problems, including energy storage, robot control, photovoltaic generators, backgammon, checkers, Go (AlphaGo), and autonomous driving systems.

## Subdisciplines

The field encompasses various specialized areas including:
- Deep reinforcement learning (deep RL), which combines reinforcement learning and deep learning
- Multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL), which focuses on studying the behavior of multiple learning agents that coexist in a shared environment

## Unmanned Aerial Vehicle Search Results

I've completed a web search for "Unmanned aerial vehicle" and found comprehensive information. Here's a summary of the key findings:

### Definition and Overview
An unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) or unmanned aircraft system (UAS), commonly known as a drone, is an aircraft with no human pilot, crew, or passengers on board, but rather is controlled remotely or is autonomous.(no content)UAVs include both autonomous drones and remotely piloted vehicles (RPVs).

### Historical Development
The earliest recorded use of an unmanned aerial vehicle for warfighting occurred in July 1849, with Austrian forces besieging Venice attempting to launch some 200 incendiary balloons at the besieged city.

### Applications
Unmanned aerial vehicles are used across the world for civilian, commercial, as well as military applications. Examples include agriculture, construction, mining, aircraft maintenance, search and rescue, and disaster response.

### Consumer Market
In 2013, DJI released the first model of the Phantom drone, which was considered one of the most influential consumer drone products ever made, with its affordability, accessibility, and user-friendly software quickly capturing the consumer drone market.

The search results provide extensive information about UAV history, types, military and civilian uses, and regulatory developments.

Links: [{"title":"Wireless network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wireless_network"},{"title":"Wireless - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wireless"},{"title":"Private Shared Wireless Network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Private_Shared_Wireless_Network"},{"title":"Mobile telephony - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mobile_telephony"},{"title":"Communication channel - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Communication_channel"},{"title":"6G (network)","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/6G_(network)"},{"title":"Base transceiver station - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Base_transceiver_station"},{"title":"Personal Communications Service - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Personal_Communications_Service"},{"title":"Base station - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Base_station"},{"title":"Wireless security - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wireless_security"}]

I've completed the web search for "Wireless network communication". Here's a summary of the key findings:

## Overview

A wireless network is a computer network that uses wireless data connections between network nodes.(no content)Wireless networking allows homes, telecommunications networks, and business installations to avoid the costly process of introducing cables into a building, or as a connection between various locations.

## Types of Wireless Networks

**Wi-Fi**: IEEE 802.11 defines a common flavor of open-standards wireless radio-wave technology known as Wi-Fi.(no content)Wi-Fi has become the de facto standard for access in private homes, within offices, and at public hotspots.

**Cellular Networks**: A cellular network or mobile network is a radio network distributed over land areas called cells, each served by at least one fixed-location transceiver, known as a cell site or base station. In a cellular network, each cell characteristically uses a different set of radio frequencies from all their immediate neighbouring cells to avoid any interference.

**Wireless Personal Area Networks (WPANs)**: Wireless personal area networks (WPANs) connect devices within a relatively small area, that is generally within a person's reach.

## Communication Technologies

Wireless data communications allow wireless networking between desktop computers, laptops, tablet computers, cell phones, and other related devices. Communication methods include radio frequency technologies, free-space optical communication, and terrestrial microwave systems.

todos.content: If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.
todos.activeForm: Fixing validation errors and rerunning validation

todos.content: Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as 'contribution' or 'survey'. Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.
todos.activeForm: Reading triples_output.json and classifying paper

todos.content: List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.
todos.activeForm: Listing and analyzing explicit triples from title/abstract

todos.content: For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.
todos.activeForm: Searching Wikipedia for each entity

todos.content: Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm"); relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes); entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other; wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/); relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters
todos.activeForm: Editing triples_output.json with all triple data

todos.content: Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py
todos.activeForm: Running validation script

todos.content: If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.
todos.activeForm: Fixing validation errors and rerunning validation
